intro: Galium sylvestre var. hispidum, commonly known as hairy woodcricket, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered with fine hairs, giving it a distinctive, hairy appearance. Galium sylvestre var. hispidum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
